Comments_List: How to think about cryptographic protocols. How to apply supposed hard problems like factoring to make a security system. How to not trust anyone, especially people named Eve and Mallory.
I have learned a  lot about Cryptography.
The course covered the basics of the field of cryptography including symmetric crypto, asymmetric crypto and other crypto primitives.

Material is really interesting, and the protocols are set to stories which make them entertaining. Homework is mind-numbing; I think actually implementing a full cryptographic protocol would be really cool. Take a page from other classes like 433: I think Yale students are totally able to implement SSL or ElGamal with elliptic curves.
Lectures are quite dry. They could be spiced up with demos. Examine a crytpographic protocol in action, or implement one in class, or have students stand up and simulate one. The math can and should be done live on the chalkboard; slideshows are terrible ways to learn.
Please continue having a math grad student as the TF.
this course focus o introduction and provide a broad view of this subject

Strength: A large array of topics were covered.

Weaknesses: The course lacked depth and was not very challenging. The homeworks, programming assignments and exams were all quite easy.
Would recommend. Lectures dry as hell. Material interesting as heaven. Homework mind-numbingly easy.
Yes, I'd like to recommend it to friends, as I have learned a lot about Cryptography.
yes! it can give you a high level idea about cryptography

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested to understand the fundamental ideas and techniques underlying key cryptography primitives including secure communication, digital signatures and cryptographic hash functions. The course assumes some maturity in mathematics.
